IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 8901 S1381-1169(13)00381-6 10.1016/j.molcata.2013.09.039 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 (a) Ni 2p3/2 and (b) Co 2p3/2 spectra of 1.4nm Ni-Co overlayer (0.54 Ni) supported on ZnO-Zn measured after deposition and at temperature range of 113–623K. The sample was heated to the marked temperature at a ramp rate of 1Ks−1 and quickly cooled down to room temperature for XPS measurements. The spectra were compared to those measured on Ni-Co deposited on the Au foil (dotted lines) and treated under the same conditions (c) Ni to Co and Ni-Co to Zn atomic ratio at various temperatures is shown in order to illustrate the change in surface atomic fraction (right part). The fraction of CoO and NiO was estimated by deconvolution of Co 2p and Ni 2p photoelectron spectra. Fig. 2 SEM images of 1.4nm Ni-Co overlayer (0.54 Ni) supported on ZnO-Zn (a) before thermal annealing treatment and (b) after flash annealing at 623K. The darker areas represent the NiCo overlayer. Fig. 3 Temperature programmed desorption spectra after saturation exposure of ethanol at 120K over 1.4nm Ni-Co/ZnO-Zn with 0.54 Ni atomic fraction. Heating rate: 1Ks−1. Fig. 4 Reaction paths for ethanol desorption on Ni-Co overlayer supported on ZnO-Zn. The major paths include: (1) dehydrogenation of OH group in ethanol molecule (Eq. (1)) (2) dehydrogenation of ethoxy group (Eq. (3)) (3) decomposition of ethoxy group by CC bond scission (Eq. (4)) and (5) decomposition of methyl group (Eq. (5)) (6) formation of CO2 by Boudouard reaction. Fig. 5 C1s spectra of bare ZnO-Zn support, thin layers of Ni-Co deposited on ZnO-Zn (Ni atomic fraction: 0.54, thickness ∼1.4nm) and Au (Ni atomic fraction: 0.5, thickness ∼1.2nm) recorded right after the TPD experiment. Fig. 6 TPD of (a) C2H4O (m/z 29) (b) H2 (m/z 2) (c) CO (m/z 28) and (d) CH4 (m/z 16) on Ni and Co layer on ZnO-Zn with Ni atomic fractions=0, 0.37, 0.54, 0.64, 1 and pure ZnO-Zn. Heating rate: 1Ks−1. Fig. 7 Temperature measured at the TPD peak maximum (T des) for methane, acetaldehyde and carbon monoxide desorption spectra over Ni-Co/ZnO-Zn with variable Ni content. Graphical abstract The interaction of ethanol with a model catalyst consisting of Ni, Co and Ni-Co nanoparticles supported on Zn terminated polar ZnO(0001) single crystals, was investigated by temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The TPD spectra recorded upon ethanol exposure on Ni-Co layers with different Ni:Co composition (Ni atomic fraction=0, 0.37, 0.54, 0.64, 1) show several desorption products as a result of ethanol dehydrogenation and decomposition reactions. XPS results revealed that the Ni-Co thin layer agglomerated upon annealing, while evidence of oxygen spillover from the ZnO support to the NiCo overlayer was found. Chemisorbed ethanol readily reacts with the model catalysts and desorbs as C2H4O (243K), CH4 (243K), H2 (258K), CO (312K and 440K) and CO2 (at 363K). Ethanol decomposition and desorption of methane is more favorable on Ni rich NiCo layers. On the other hand, dehydrogenation of ethanol and production of acetaldehyde is more pronounced on cobalt. In addition, mobile oxygen from the ZnO support participates to the oxidation of carbonaceous species at higher temperatures, preventing carbon deposition. This work provides new insights into the intrinsic reactivity of ethanol over NiCo-ZnO, which can be of a great importance in understanding the selectivity and stability of these catalysts in the ethanol steam reforming reaction. Abbreviations TPD temperature programmed desorption XPS X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy SEM scanning electronic microscopy B.E. binding energy ESR ethanol steam reforming T des temperature at the peak maximum Keywords Nickel Cobalt Bimetallic catalyst ZnO Ethanol decomposition 1 Introduction Ethanol steam reforming (ESR) is an important catalytic reaction for the production of hydrogen from biomass [1–6]. Nickel and cobalt supported on metal oxides show excellent ethanol conversion efficiency and hydrogen selectivity [7,8], with the major drawback being their fast deactivation. Bimetallic catalysts composed of these two metals are of particular interest for the improvement of catalyst's stability and deactivation resistance [9–17]. Major by-products from ESR reaction such as acetaldehyde, methane, ethylene and carbon monoxide have been identified in a number of studies on working catalysts [18–22]. In the catalytic studies of Freni et al. [21], Ni/MgO shows higher activity than Co/MgO due to the lower tendency of Ni to get oxidized. In addition, Ni/MgO suppresses more efficiently ethanol decomposition and CO methanation. The study by Bichon et al. [23] also shows that Ni and Co catalysts supported on Al2O3 are highly comparable in ethanol conversion efficiency and hydrogen yield. However, the amount of carbon deposition is significantly lower on Co/Al2O3. Padilla et al. [24] have investigated the major reaction intermediates involved on lanthana promoted Co/ZrO2 and Ni/ZrO2 by using temperature programmed reaction-desorption. It was proposed that adsorbed ethanol is dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde, which undergoes different evolution mechanism on the two catalytic systems. On the Co-based catalyst, acetaldehyde undergoes reforming reaction, while on the Ni-based one, acetaldehyde is transformed to ethylene and acetone. The catalytic activity of Ni and Co as a bimetallic working metal catalyst has been studied by Resini et al. [11]. It was shown that methane formation was reduced with the addition of Co to Ni/YSZ, and the hydrogen yield at low temperature was improved. On the other hand, Chen et al. [10] have found that the addition of Co does not improve the activity of Ni catalyst (supported on Ca-γ-Al2O3 and ZrO2). The intrinsic reactivity of the two metals to the ESR reaction and possible synergetic effects upon alloying, remain to be resolved. Identification of the intermediate reactions on a catalytic surface can facilitate the determination of the desirable reaction pathway and can improve catalyst's design. The reactivity of ethanol involves a series of intermediate reaction pathways and metastable intermediate species. Major reaction paths include ethanol decomposition, dehydrogenation, decarbonylation and dehydration, which all involve different energy barriers. Reforming reactions are favored at high temperatures, while decomposition proceeds at low temperatures. Under most reaction conditions, formation of ethylene and acetaldehyde takes part as the initial step of ESR [7,23,25]. These two species, however, are thermodynamically unstable [26,27]. Thus, when the reaction is in equilibrium, acetaldehyde is just an intermediate product and is prompt to further reaction by either reforming or decomposition. Steam-to-water ratio, temperature and pressure are crucial factors for ESR. A number of thermodynamic studies have been conducted to illustrate the stability of different reaction intermediates and to assess the correlation between the product yield and these critical parameters [26–35]. Hydrogen yield increases with temperature, pressure and water to ethanol feed ratio, while selectivity to CO and CH4 as well as carbon formation rise when the water to ethanol feed ratio is too low [28,29,35]. The various intermediate reaction paths involve different bond dissociation sequences, i.e. CH, CC, OH and CO dissociation. The reactions of ethanol on nickel [36,37] and cobalt [38,39] single crystals have been studied with surface techniques such as temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Ni has been regarded as an efficient catalyst for CC bond scission, generating methane as one of the major products [40]. The study by Hyman and Vohs [38] on ethanol thermal decomposition on Co (0001) has shown that acetaldehyde, CO and H2 are the major decomposition products. Apart from the metal, the influence of the oxide support is critical for the catalytic stability. ZnO is regarded as an appropriate support material for ESR catalysts thanks to its mild acidity [41]. The TPD study on ZnO nanorods by Geunjae and Kijung shows that ethanol is mainly decomposed through dehydrogenation forming acetaldehyde [42], but is not active for further decomposition. Despite its rather inert role in catalytic reaction, oxygen from the ZnO support could suppress coke formation on the catalyst [43–45]. The study of the elementary reaction steps on a model catalyst system can improve our understanding of the catalytic process. So far, most of the basic studies on the ethanol surface chemistry have been conducted on metal single crystals. Thin Ni, Co and NiCo overlayers supported on a ZnO(0001)-Zn single crystal (denoted as ZnO-Zn in the following text) is adopted here as an appropriate model system, which takes into account both the metal reactivity and the support effect. TPD is a relatively direct method to study the ethanol surface chemistry on such a model system. The objective of this work is to compare the mechanism of ethanol adsorption and reaction over monometallic and bimetallic Ni-Co overlayers and elucidates the effect of the ZnO support. Our results can be used to rationalize the performance of these materials in the ethanol steam reforming reaction. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Experimental apparatus The experiments were carried out in an ultra-high vacuum (UHV) chamber (base pressure <2×10−9 mbar) equipped with a VG Microtech Clam2 electron analyzer, a dual anode (Al Kα and Mg Kα) X-ray source for XPS, a gas dosing system with a pinhole diaphragm and a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS, Thermo Scientific VGQ100) for TPD. The sample was mounted on a molybdenum sample holder that can be heated at the back side by electron bombardment and can be cooled down to 100K via a liquid nitrogen reservoir. A power supply (Prevac Heat 2PS) with an integrated PID controller was used to control the linear heating ramp and the temperature was monitored with a K-type thermocouple attached on the side of the sample surface. 2.2 Preparation of Ni-Co overlayers on ZnO-Zn The model NiCo/ZnO catalyst consists of metal clusters deposited on a planar ZnO substrate. This system can facilitate the study of the metal-support interaction to the reactivity, compared to the much more complex powder catalyst. One sided polished ZnO-Zn single crystal (10mm×10mm×0.33mm, Crystec) was used as the substrate. ZnO crystallizes into the wurtzite structure consisting of alternating planes of Zn and O atoms, arranged in threefold coordinated layers and separated by single ZnO bond. The surface that was used as a support in this study is formed by a direct truncation of the ZnO crystal lattice in the (0001)-axis that provides a Zn terminated polar surface. Prior to metal evaporation, the ZnO-Zn substrates were cleaned by repeated cycles of Ar+ sputtering followed by annealing at 773K in 1×10−6 mbar O2. This procedure was repeated until a clean ZnO(0001) surface was obtained as determined by XPS and LEED. Ni and/or Co were (co)-evaporated in-situ on the clean ZnO substrate using a commercial e-beam evaporator (QUAD-EV-C, Mantis Deposition Ltd.). The water-cooled evaporator head is composed of 4 electrically independent pockets that can operate simultaneously for co-evaporation. Integrated flux monitoring plates in each pocket allows real-time feedback of the deposition rate during evaporation. The source is equipped with a manual shutter that maintains a well-timed evaporation period at a controlled evaporation flux. 2.3 XPS and SEM experiments The XPS spectra were processed with background subtraction by Shirley method. The atomic ratios of the elements were obtained from the corresponding peak areas normalized by the atomic sensitivity factors [46]. The thickness of the as deposited Ni-Co, Ni and Co layers was estimated by the ion flux detected by the monitor plates of the metal evaporator and was confirmed by calculations based on the decrease of the Zn 2p intensity, supposing exponential attenuation of the intensity with the overlayer thickness. The morphology of NiCo/ZnO-Zn model catalysts before and after the thermal treatment was inspected by scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) using a Jeol JSM-6700F field emission scanning electron microscope. 2.4 TPD experiments Ethanol (pro analysis grade) was purified by successive freeze pump-thaw cycles and the purity was verified by the QMS. Dosing of ethanol was performed via a stainless steel tube (6mm diameter) directed above the sample surface, in a distance of about 2mm. A pinhole diaphragm (pinhole diameter 15μm) at the end of the dosage tube was used to assure uniform exposure of ethanol vapor over the sample. In addition, this system allows local exposure on the sample surface, with almost negligible gas load to the vacuum and a minimum contamination of the sample holder and the chamber walls. The pinhole doser was connected to the ethanol reservoir through a leak valve, which was kept open for a fixed period of time (10s) during each exposure. This procedure produces saturated multilayer ethanol exposure on the sample as judged by presence of a physisorbed ethanol desorption peak in all cases. The quadrupole mass spectrometer is equipped with an individually pumped cylindrical tube ending in a cone with a hole of diameter 1cm. Just before sample annealing and TPD spectra recording, the sample was positioned in front of the mass spectrometer tube at a distance of about 1mm. This allows an almost background-free measurement of desorption products from the sample's surface. The TPD experiments were performed with a linear heating rate of 1Ks−1. The H2 (m/z =2) CH4 (m/z =16), H2O (m/z =18), C2H4 (m/z =27), C2H4O (m/z =29), CO (m/z =28) and CO2 (m/z =44) masses were recorded for the identification of major ethanol reaction products. Since there is a marked overlapping between the mass fragments of the possible desorption products, separate calibration experiments of the QMS were performed, in which all possible desorption products were individually introduced into the chamber and their fragmentation pattern was measured. To facilitate the presentation and comprehension of the TPD results, the mass signal after subtraction of the fragments from other desorption products will be presented here. The sensitivities of the Bayert–Albert ionization gauge and the mass spectrometer, as well as the contribution of the fragmentation pattern were taken into account for the calculations of desorption peak area ratios. A blank experiment of ethanol thermal desorption on an inert substrate (clean gold foil) was performed in order to estimate the impact of background gas traces to the desorption spectra. The experiments indicated that the background signal is practically negligible. In order to avoid accumulation of water originating from residual water vapor in the UHV chamber during cooling, the sample was flash annealed to 323K prior to TPD experiments and cooled down quickly before dosing. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Thermal stability of Ni-Co/ZnO-Zn The model Ni-Co/ZnO catalyst was prepared by (co)deposition of metal(s) on an atomically clean ZnO-Zn substrate at room temperature. As shown in our previous work, annealing of Ni-Co/ZnO under UHV conditions induces agglomeration and partial oxidation of the Ni-Co overlayer [47]. Therefore, annealing cycles unavoidably stimulate morphological modifications of the freshly deposited Ni-Co layers in the course of the TPD experiment. In order to monitor the change in composition and metal distribution brought by the first TPD cycle, a freshly deposited 1.4nm NiCo/ZnO sample was annealed (heating rate 1Ks−1) while XPS spectra were recorded at various temperatures. The Ni 2p3/2 and Co 2p3/2 photoelectron spectra recorded before (120K) and after flash annealing at 623K is presented in Fig. 1a and b. In addition, spectra recorded under identical conditions over 1.3nm Ni-Co co-deposited on a polycrystalline Au foil are included as a reference. The as deposited Ni and Co layers are metallic on both ZnO and the reference Au substrate, as indicated by the binding energy (B.E.) of the Ni 2p3/2 and Co 2p3/2 at 852.7eV and at 778.3eV respectively [48,49]. At the maximum annealing temperature (623K), cobalt supported on ZnO-Zn is partially oxidized, as indicated by the binding energy shift of the Co2p3/2 peak from 778.5eV to 781.6eV and the characteristic shake-up satellite at higher BEs. On the contrary, Ni remains metallic despite the heavy Co oxidation. On the other hand, under identical conditions cobalt supported on Au substrate remains in the metallic state. From the comparison above, it is evident that the interaction with ZnO-Zn is the origin of Co oxidation upon annealing at high temperatures. Fig. 1c summarizes the change of the Ni-Co surface composition and oxidation state as a function of temperature. The Ni-Co:Zn ratio calculated from the photoelectron spectra is an indication of Ni-Co overlayer agglomeration, while the Ni:Co ratio is indicative for the surface mixing between the two metals. As is evident up to 450K the Ni-Co composition and oxidation state is practically stable, while above this temperature severe Ni-Co overlayer agglomeration is observed. In addition, the Ni:Co ratio decreases above 550K, which indicates segregation of Co over Ni. Taking into account the parallel oxidation of Co observed at this temperature (as shown in Fig. 1c), one can conclude that surface segregation of cobalt over nickel is driven by cobalt oxidation and is not solely a temperature effect. The surface morphology of the model catalysts before and after the thermal treatment was studied by SEM. Before annealing, the NiCo film on ZnO-Zn forms a homogeneous smooth surface (darker area in Fig. 2a), while only minor parts of the ZnO-Zn surface is uncovered (brighter area in Fig. 2a). After thermal treatment, the NiCo film on ZnO-Zn showed a different surface microstructure, i.e. is agglomerated into NiCo islands. Post-TPD SEM images are in accordance with the XPS results, showing that the NiCo overlayer undergoes agglomeration after annealing at the maximum temperature. The thermal stability of the NiCo/ZnO-Zn, as revealed by the spectroscopic and microscopic results, has two direct implications on the interpretation of the TPD studies. Firstly, it is demonstrated that apart from the NiCo film agglomeration, the surface Ni:Co composition and the oxidation state of Co remain stable up to 450K. Secondly, severe Co oxidation above this temperature indicates that mobile oxygen species from the ZnO support readily react with Co at elevated temperatures. Although oxidation of the metal adlayer is observed only above 450K, it is probable that spillover of oxygen on Ni and Co begins at lower temperatures and affects the reactivity of the adsorbed ethanol. The preferential oxidation of Co compared to Ni, might justify the beneficial effect of Co in reducing carbon deposition over Ni-based ethanol steam reforming catalysts. Cobalt can increase the oxygen concentration on the catalyst's surface (derived either from the support or from the gas feed). As a consequence, it enhances the oxidation of adsorbed carbon prohibiting the deactivation of the catalyst due to cocking. 3.2 The reactivity of ethanol on bimetallic Ni-Co/ZnO alloy overlayers The reactivity of ethanol over 1.4nm NiCo/ZnO-Zn with Ni atomic fraction 0.54 is discussed based on the TPD results. Fig. 3 shows the TPD spectra after saturation ethanol exposure at 120K. Five products are observed during desorption: H2, CH4, CO, C2H4O, and CO2. As shown, mass fragments for other possible desorption species, like C2H5OH, H2O and C2H4, were also recorded without evident desorption peaks. C2H4O and CH4 desorb simultaneously with peak maximum (T des) at 243K, while the following products desorb subsequently at higher T des: H2 (at 258K), CO (at 312 and 440K) and CO2 (at 365K). The two vertical dotted lines in the figure indicate the initiation temperature of NiCo agglomeration and Co oxidation, as revealed by the temperature-programmed XPS experiments presented above. As is evident in Fig. 3, desorption of all species is completed well before Co oxidation, while severe NiCo agglomeration interferes only with the 2nd CO desorption peak. Therefore one can assume that both the sample morphology and the surface oxidation state are practically stable in the course of the TPD experiment. Desorption of ethanol over transition metals is complex and can be attributed to several surface reactions (please refer to the reaction scheme of Fig. 4 ). It has been well demonstrated in previous studies that the initial pathway of ethanol decomposition takes place via the dissociative adsorption of ethanol and the scission of the OH bond (Eq. (1)). This leads to the formation of ethoxy (CH3CH2O) groups and atomic hydrogen on the surface, as the major intermediate for further processes [50]. (1) CH3CH2OH(g)→CH3CH2O(ads)+H(ads) The fact that the dehydrogenation of hydroxyl groups appears commonly as the first step in the bond decomposition sequence [36,51,52] can be explained by the relatively low OH bond dissociation energy barrier and the relatively high stability of the remaining ethoxy group, according to recent theoretical studies [53]. The surface ethoxy groups can be consumed by different reaction pathways, namely dehydration, dehydrogenation and decomposition: (2) CH3CH2O(ads)+H(ads)→C2H4(g)+H2O(g)(dehydration) (3) CH3CH2O(ads)+H(ads)→C2H4O(g)+H2(g)(dehydrogenation) (4) CH3CH2O(ads)+H(ads)→CH4(g)+CO(g)+H2(g)(decomposition) (5) CH4(ads)→C(ads)+2H2(g)(decomposition) (6) 2CO(ads)→C(ads)+CO2(g)(Boudouard reaction) In the present study H2O and C2H4 are not observed among the desorption products (see Fig. 3) hence the dehydration of ethanol (Eq. (2)) is negligible. Dehydrogenation, by the removal of α-hydrogen from the ethoxy group, leads to the formation of C2H4O and H2 according to Eq. (3). Desorption of these products at about 250K is clearly observed in Fig. 3, confirming the activity of NiCo/ZnO-Zn to this reaction path. Alternatively, molecular C2H4O can remain adsorbed and undergo further decomposition with final desorption products being CH4, H2 and CO (Eq. (4)). Since these products are also observed, ethanol decomposition takes place in parallel to dehydrogenation. As is evident in Fig. 3, a second CO peak (further abbreviated as 2nd CO) also appears at higher temperature (ca. 450K). This peak has been observed in previous studies and has been attributed to the oxidation of surface carbonaceous species by surface oxygen. Surface carbon can be produced by decomposition of adsorbed CH4 (Eq. (5)) or the Boudouard reaction (Eq. (6)). It has been proposed that the intensity of the 2nd CO desorption peak depends on the availability of surface oxygen and of the carbon produced during prior decomposition processes (e.g. Eqs. (5) and (6)) [38]. These species recombine at higher temperatures and desorb as CO. It was also shown that the intensity of the 2nd CO desorption peak is minor on unsupported Co (0001) [38], but much more significant on Co/CeO2/YSZ(100) [54]. Therefore the intensity of the 2nd CO peak depends on the quantity of oxygen species available for the oxidation of surface carbon. In reducible supports like CeO2 [54] or ZnO oxygen can mobilize (at elevated temperatures) and migrate to the NiCo layer for the oxidation of carbon species that remain on the surface after the ethanol decomposition. The high mobility of oxygen from the ZnO-Zn substrate is manifested in the XPS results discussed above. The continuous increase in the CO2 signal observed after the CO2 desorption peak at 365K, might be due to the oxidation of different type of residual surface carbon. Overall, the detected TPD products indicate that ethanol desorption over NiCo/ZnO-Zn follows both dehydrogenation and decomposition reaction paths, while the ZnO support is actively involved by providing oxygen species, especially at higher temperatures. The C 1s XPS peak recorded on NiCo/ZnO-Zn and on the bare ZnO-Zn substrate (see Fig. 5 ) after the TPD run showed no evidence of carbon deposition, indicating that either the desorption of ethanol was complete, or the residual carbon species after the TPD cycle are below the detection limit of XPS (<0.1 equivalent monolayer). On the contrary, when identical TPD cycles are performed on the Au-supported NiCo, carbon deposition (about 0.3equiv. monolayers) is evident according to the C 1s spectra recorded after TPD. This result further confirms the key role of the ZnO-Zn support on the elimination of surface carbon species. 3.3 The effect of Ni-Co mixing ratio on the ethanol reactivity In order to compare the ethanol reactivity on Ni and Co, as well as the synergetic effect of the two metals, TPD results on overlayers with different Ni-Co composition are compared (see Table 1 ). Three Ni to Co mixing ratios were investigated along with monometallic samples, while the overall thickness of the Ni-Co layer is kept at 1.2±0.2nm. The complete set of TPD results for C2H4O, H2, CO and CH4 for monometallic and bimetallic samples with different Ni-Co compositions are compared in Fig. 6 . The results from the clean ZnO-Zn substrate are also included for comparison. A constant ethanol exposure up to saturation level has been used in all TPD experiments. C2H4O and H2 are the primary ethanol decomposition products on both monometallic and bimetallic Ni-Co layers (Fig. 6a and b). An additional low intensity C2H4O peak at about 357K, coinciding with the T des on bare ZnO-Zn, is also observed. This peak can be assigned to desorption from uncovered sites of the ZnO substrate, in accordance to the SEM results (Fig. 2a). The H2 desorption peak (between 260 and 270K) is asymmetric and is extended at higher temperature. On both Ni and Co/ZnO-Zn metal layer, hydrogen desorption is primarily the result of ethanol OH and ethoxy group dehydrogenation (Eqs. (1) and (3)). Decomposition of adsorbed CH3CH2O and CH4 at slightly different temperature, can justify the wide H2 desorption peak profile. The common ethanol decomposition products, CO and CH4, are observed on Ni and Co containing samples, but not on the bare ZnO substrate (Fig. 6c and d). A major difference between Ni/ZnO-Zn and Co/ZnO-Zn lies mainly on the more pronounced formation of methane on Ni/ZnO-Zn compared to Co, indicating that on Co either Eq. 4 is suppressed or Eq. (5) is favored. From Fig. 6, it can be remarked that there is a clear difference of the T des between CH4 and CO. In particular, the T des of CH4 is found at about 250K for all samples, which is much lower than the T des of CO which appears above 300K. Formation of adsorbed methyl and CO groups could originate from the single step of CC bond scission according to reaction 4. The difference in T des between CH4 and CO shows that after CC bond scission, CH4 desorbs first, while the CO group remains adsorbed and desorbs at higher temperature. A 2nd broad CO desorption peak is found at about 450K. As mentioned before, this is the product of surface carbon oxidation by the mobile oxygen species of the substrate. Since oxygen mobility depends mainly on the substrate temperature, there is no pronounced difference between the T des of the 2nd CO peaks for different Ni-Co ratios. The T des of CH4, C2H4O, and the first CO peak as a function of the Ni fraction are compared in Fig. 7 . The T des of CH4 and C2H4O on Ni-Co/ZnO-Zn does not deviate significantly from that on monometallic Ni/ZnO-Zn and is about 10K lower than that on Co/ZnO-Zn. The proximity of the T des of bimetallic Ni-Co layer with monometallic Ni indicates that Ni exerts a dominating influence over Co in CH4 and C2H4O desorption. This can be rationalized by preferential dehydrogenation (Eq. (3)) of ethoxy groups on Ni surface sites. Segregation of nickel over cobalt on the bimetallic surface and elimination of all Co surface sites should be excluded, since this is not supported by the XPS results (Fig. 1c), which show that both metals intermix with a ratio close to the nominal value. Intermixing with Co does not induce significant electronic effect on Ni that could influence the adsorption strength, and thus the T des, of CH4 and C2H4O. On the other hand, the T des of CO increases linearly with increasing Ni content up to about 30K. By the basic principles of desorption theory and assuming first-order desorption kinetics, the higher T des of CO corresponds to the stronger bond strength between CO and the metal. The linear correlation of the T des of the 1st CO peak with the Ni atomic fraction could correspond to the weakening of the CO bond, as the Co content increases in the layer. This is also reflected by the systematic difference in the adsorption energy of CO on Ni and Co single crystal surfaces estimated by DFT calculations [55], showing that the adsorption energy of CO on Co(0001) is more positive than on Ni (111). The decrease of the adsorption energy of CO on Ni (111) by the addition of Co has also been estimated from the theoretical calculations of Liu et al. [56]. The difference in the trend of T des between CO and CH4 indicates that after ethanol decomposition the two products occupy different types of surface adsorption sites. Consequently, it is proposed that the synergetic effect between the two metals preferentially affects a particular reaction path, generating considerable effects on the products’ selectivity. Since C2H4O, CH4 and CO are derived from the same adsorbed ethoxy species, the two reaction paths (Eqs. (3) and (4)) are competitive. The decomposition of ethoxy species into CH4 and CO by CC bond dissociation is an activated process and therefore at higher temperature will proceed at a much higher rate. Consequently, the lower desorption temperature of molecular C2H4O on the Ni-containing samples (see Fig. 7) prevents dissociation of ethoxy species to CH4 and CO, and favors desorption of molecular C2H4O. In the theoretical study of Wang et al. [53] it is shown that the ethoxy intermediate formed on the Co surface is more stable than the one adsorbed on the Ni. On the other hand, on the cobalt sample, the higher desorption temperature of molecular C2H4O leads to the higher dissociation rate of CH4 and CO. The interaction of CH4 and CO with the Ni-Co surface determines whether the adsorption of these products takes place as molecular (Eq. (4)) or dissociative (Eqs. (5) and (6)) chemisorption. In our case the higher level of CH4 decomposition on Co is reflected by the higher T des observed, as shown in Fig. 7, while Boudouard reaction is enhanced as the Ni content increases. To summarize, the interaction of ethoxy species with NiCo surfaces produces 3 main adsorbates: C2H4O, CH4 and CO. Depending of their bond strength with the substrate, these adsorbates can undergo molecular or dissociative adsorption. Since the two adsorption states are competitive, the higher the desorption temperature of the molecular species, the greater their possibility to dissociate. The observed difference of the T des on the different NiCo surface compositions corresponds well to the desorption peak area of each desorption product. Representative area ratios between different desorption products, normalized to the maximum value, and are presented in Fig. 8 . The CO to C2H4O area ratio (Fig. 8a) is characteristic for the preference to dehydrogenation or decomposition reaction path (Eq. (3) or Eq. (4)). CO production is favored on Co, while the addition of Ni into Co enhances production of C2H4O. This indicates that ethanol dehydrogenation (Eq. (3)) occurs at sufficiently high rate on Ni-containing samples compared to the decomposition reaction path (Eq. (4)). It is also interesting to note that the CO production increases at a Ni surface fraction of about 0.6, which is consistent to the observed increase of the T des of C2H4O shown in Fig. 7. The CH4 to CO ratio shown in Fig. 8b can be regarded as an indicator of the ability of the catalyst to decompose CH4 and CO according to the Eqs. (5) and (6). For example, low CH4 to CO ratio suggests that CH4 decomposition is the preferred reaction path, since relatively more CO is produced. The linear correlation of CH4:CO ratio to the Ni content reveals that the CH4 desorption is enhanced with increasing fraction of Ni. This indicates higher activity of Co toward the dissociation of CH4 or respectively higher rate of the Boudouard reaction over Ni. Theoretical calculations show that the energy barrier of dehydrogenation of methyl group on Co (111) is lower than that on Ni (111) [53], which supports the proposition that dehydrogenation of the methyl group occurs mainly on the Co surface in comparison to Ni. The work from Burghgraef et al. [57] has also revealed that the energy barrier of most of the reaction steps involved in the dehydrogenation of CH4 is lower on a Co metal cluster. Though on Ni surface the feasibility of CH bond scission has been proven by isotope exchange [37], it is shown clearly in the above TPD results that on Ni/ZnO-Zn, the methyl group tends to recombine with hydrogen and desorbs as methane. It has also been shown in the theoretical study of Wang et al., that the Boudouard reaction is more favored on Ni (111) than the CH4 sequential dehydrogenation [58]. The dissociative CO adsorption is the initial step of the Boudouard reaction. The reaction is structure sensitive and in UHV studies is initiated on the Ni (997) surface at 350K [59], while for the Ni (111) at 400K [60]. On the other hand, on Co surfaces CO dissociation is barely observed. The CO is molecularly adsorbed on Co(0001), while dissociation might take place upon adsorption at defect sites [61,62]. Only at relatively high CO pressures and temperature (300mbar, 520K), CO dissociation on Co(0001) was observed [63]. On Co ( 1 1 2 ¯ 0 ) [64] and Co ( 1 0 1 ¯ 2 ) [65] CO dissociation may take place only at high temperatures. The production of H2 with respect to the other hydrogen containing desorption products (CH4 and C2H4O) is shown in Fig. 8c. Hydrogen production is favored over Co, while the addition of Ni suppresses the production of H2 compared to CH4 and C2H4O. Hydrogen can be produced by 3 reaction paths (Eqs. (3), (4) and (5)) but only Eq. (5) leads to carbon deposition. Assuming that all deposited carbon desorbs at higher temperature as the 2nd CO peak, the H2 to 2nd CO peak ratio can be used to correlate H2 production with carbon deposition. It is shown in Fig. 8d that carbon deposition is more pronounced on Ni compared to Co, but interestingly the bimetallic NiCo gives a quite broad range of values. This observation can reflect the complexity of carbon deposition process, which involves not only the strength of interaction between the surface CO and CH4 molecules, but also their relative production by the various reaction paths. This signifies that there is a particular NiCo surface composition (between 0.37 and 0.54 in this study) in which the bimetallic catalysts can be beneficial in terms of hydrogen production and carbon deposition compared to the monometallic ones. From the above comparison, one can conclude that the principal reaction paths of ethanol over ZnO-supported Ni and Co are quite different. Nickel favors decomposition, while cobalt dehydrogenation of ethanol. The initial step for the surface reaction of ethanol takes place by dehydrogenation of OH group, which leads to the formation of adsorbed ethoxy intermediate. The composition of the bimetallic layer substantially influences the subsequent decomposition of the ethoxy intermediate. Further dehydrogenation from H2CO group of the ethoxy intermediate can be easily activated on the Ni-Co overlayer, which gives rise to production of acetaldehyde and hydrogen. Alternatively, ethoxy group may further decompose by the breaking of CC bond. On Ni rich thin bimetallic layers, CC bond scission produces CH4 and CO while on Co rich layers, methane desorption is much more limited. Our results propose that it may exist a critical NiCo composition above which a non-negligible alteration of reaction path and ultimately product selectivity may occur. This could explain the inconsistency in the modification of the reaction efficiency and H2 selectivity on the working catalyst system [11,66]. Improvement of catalytic activities of Ni-Co bimetallic materials would require precise selection of the composition between the two elements. In addition to that, deactivation can be limited by stabilizing the surface composition of the NiCo catalyst during the catalytic life cycle. 4 Conclusions This study compares the reaction paths of ethanol over monometallic and bimetallic Ni-Co thin films supported on a ZnO single crystal. It was shown that the intrinsic reactivity of ethanol over the two metals is different, with Ni favoring production of methane and cobalt of acetaldehyde. Synergetic effects due to the mixing of Ni and Co may induce significant modifications to the ethanol desorption products. Thus, thorough control of the Ni-Co composition is needed for optimal product selectivity. At elevated temperatures the ZnO support provides oxygen species, which not only promote oxidation of residual carbon generated after ethanol desorption, but also lead to the preferential oxidation of cobalt over nickel. Addition of cobalt on Ni-containing catalyst may benefit the ESR reaction by increasing the surface oxygen concentration, yet one should be cautious since facile formation of cobalt oxides might suppress the overall activity. coredata.dc:description: The interaction of ethanol with a model catalyst consisting of Ni, Co and Ni-Co nanoparticles supported on Zn terminated polar ZnO(0001) single crystals, was investigated by temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The TPD spectra recorded upon ethanol exposure on Ni-Co layers with different Ni:Co composition (Ni atomic fraction=0, 0.37, 0.54, 0.64, 1) show several desorption products as a result of ethanol dehydrogenation and decomposition reactions. XPS results revealed that the Ni-Co thin layer agglomerated upon annealing, while evidence of oxygen spillover from the ZnO support to the NiCo overlayer was found. Chemisorbed ethanol readily reacts with the model catalysts and desorbs as C2H4O (243K), CH4 (243K), H2 (258K), CO (312K and 440K) and CO2 (at 363K). Ethanol decomposition and desorption of methane is more favorable on Ni rich NiCo layers. On the other hand, dehydrogenation of ethanol and production of acetaldehyde is more pronounced on cobalt. In addition, mobile oxygen from the ZnO support participates to the oxidation of carbonaceous species at higher temperatures, preventing carbon deposition. This work provides new insights into the intrinsic reactivity of ethanol over NiCo-ZnO, which can be of a great importance in understanding the selectivity and stability of these catalysts in the ethanol steam reforming reaction.
coredata.dc:title: A comparative study of ethanol reactivity over Ni, Co and NiCo-ZnO model catalysts
